Synopsis

In this astonishing twelve-part project for and about television Ã¢â‚¬â€ the title of which refers to a 19th-century French primer Le tour de la France par deux enfants Ã¢â‚¬â€ Godard and MiÃƒÂ©ville take a detour through the everyday lives of two children in contemporary France.

This complex, intimately scaled study of the effect of television on the French family is constructed around GodardÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s interviews with a school girl and school boy, Camille and Arnaud. GodardÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s provocative questions to the children range from the philosophical (Ã¢â‚¬Å“Do you think you have an existence?Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½) to the social (Ã¢â‚¬Å“What does revolution mean to you?Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½). Using precise formal devices, including the extended take, slow motion, closeups, and the freeze frame, Godard and MiÃƒÂ©ville Ã¢â‚¬Å“decomposeÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ the quotidian world of their young subjects by focusing on the minutiae of the everyday and isolated gesture, the significance of a gaze. In one remarkable sequence, the fixed camera remains on a close-up of Camille as she sits in silence at the dinner table, while her parents hold an extended conversation offscreen. Another extended sequence observes Arnaud in the classroom.

The childrenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s interviews (titled VeritÃƒÂ©) and scenes of their everyday routines at home and at school (TÃƒÂ©lÃƒÂ©vision) are followed by the ironic commentary of two adult television journalists (Histoire) who provide a history/story that elaborates on the interviews. Intercut with multi-textual collages of television, cinema and advertising images, these discursive visual essays analyze the economic, social and ideological functions of the mass media.
